So text formatting has been added to Signal, which was discussed here. However, text formatting is done through highlighting the text and clicking around in a menu. As the original request actually asks for, it would be great if it were possible to use Markdown styling for formatting the text. Here’s an example from the original feature request:

*Italic*
_Italic_
**Bold**
__Bold__
~Strike through~
``*Escaped not italic*``
```*Escaped not italic*```

In my opinion this is way more useful than having to click around a menu just to itilize text

The statement was about Markdown as a whole, or even just the styling subset mentioned in the OP. You are correct that ``` isn’t very likely to occur in text, but that’s not what was stated. There are plenty of situations where *, _, or even ~ might be used in text where they were not intended to be Markdown.

Also, what is the worst that can happen? The sender can always edit their message if they accidentally made something italic. We could also make Markdown syntax formatting of sent messages opt-in.

Just make it opt-in. I’m staring at a “Show text formatting popover when text is selected” checkbox in the preferences right now. There are even four other options in just this one section of the preferences. We have the technology, the time is now.

Herohtar:

prevent unintended styling when people paste in text that contains Markdown characters

To be honest, that shouldn’t be a problem. You could automatically prefix all markdown-related characters in a pasted piece of text with the backslash (\) to escape the formatting. That way we get the best of both worlds: pasting works as intended (except if you intended to paste with formatting) and we get markdown.

That creates a different problem; now you can’t paste things that are supposed to be markdown without going back through and cleaning out escape characters, and people unfamiliar with markdown get confused by Signal inserting characters in their pasted text.

I’ve just been implementing a Signal bot (using signal-cli & signalbot frameworks).

I really lament the lack of Markdown. As soon as you involve an LLM it is clear Markdown formatting is sorely lacking.

The world made Markdown a standard and I passionately believe, especially in the modern AI world, Signal should use that standard.

There’s nothing wrong with a WYSIWYG editor, so long as the underlying encoding is in markdown.

Look at Discourse - they are doing it right - they are building a WYSIWYG editor ON TOP of markdown.

posts.cooked:
I strongly support the addition of Markdown-formatting to Signal. When this formatting decision was originally made, it may have been a forward-looking design choice, but now in late 2025 the landscape has shifted: almost everyone uses AI platforms like ChatGPT (this post was made less human by one ), and those platforms regularly output Markdown-formatted text. When we copy and paste a message from an AI into Signal, we’re forced to manually strip out all the Markdown (e.g., *italics*, **bold**, `code`) or otherwise go through annoying workarounds. Most users who copy/paste from AI have no idea what “Markdown” even is: they just see weird characters or formatting failures.

It would be so straightforward (and user-friendly) to add a settings toggle in Signal allowing each user to choose how Markdown syntax is handled:

  • Option A: Interpret Markdown, so pasted *bold*, _italics_, `code` etc render correctly.

  • Option B: Display raw text, so everything remains literally as pasted (for users who dislike auto‐formatting).

  • Option C: Strip Markdown formatting entirely on paste (so users see only clean plain text).

This is a small improvement that results in a big user-experience win.

I would not appreciate to have markdown in Signal. Markdown is great for blogs, websites, text-files etc. But Signal is for messaging and it would be overkill to have functions that are not needed by almost all people.

I never missed formatting in my messages.

E.g. if I want to emphasize a word or an expression, I can surround them with stars (like in Markdown, but without auto-formatting is italics, bold or anything else).

Or I can use a (!) after the word.

Or I can type the word in all-caps. (I know, that some people see all-caps as shouting, but that is from the early days of the Internet (back with Usenet, before the WWW), but today more and more people use all-caps for emphasizing and emojis for emotions but no “shouting” in text-messages. And even if you don’t like this one, there are enough other ways for emphasizing (see above).

And if somebody types longer text-messages, you don’t need markdown too. Because you can use paragraphs by inserting blank lines (double return). You can even use paragraphs with a short sentence that have the function of a subheadline. (But how many people really use this? And even they could use this.)

Conclusion:
In my opinion most people don’t need markdown in a messager. And because it has to be considered for every additional feature, if it is needed or not (because every additional feature means more functions and worse clearness of the GUI, I think this shouldn’t be done.

Of course, for every idea, you find people who like it. But not every first idea is useful, when you really think about it, its consequences and its alternatives.
If you don’t want to use markdown then nothing would be different for you. For those of us who want it, it would be a useful feature.

@Akikou

But it’s not only about using it by myself, but also receiving messages full of markdown. And IMHO that’s not necassary for messaging (although I love markdown in forums, blogs, etc.).
You’re already receiving messages with formatted text. Why does it matter to you if the sender formatted it with markdown or with a menu button?
